inference:
A graph represents a function if every vertical line intersects the graph at at most one point.

A: The vertical line test fails for this graph, as there are vertical lines that intersect the graph at more than one point. Not a function.

B: The graph is a circle.  A vertical line can intersect the circle at more than one point. Not a function.

C: The graph is a straight line.  A vertical line can intersect the line at more than one point.  Not a function.

D: The graph consists of two parts.  One part is a quarter of a circle and the other is a straight line segment. A vertical line can intersect the first part of the graph at more than one point. Not a function.

E: The graph consists of two parts, the upper and lower parts of the graph of $y = \sqrt{x+2}$.  Every vertical line intersects the graph at at most one point. This is a function.

Final Answer: $\boxed{E}$
ground_truth: A diagram represents the graph of a function if and only if every vertical line intersects the graph at most once.  The only diagrams that have this property are $\boxed{\text{A,D}}.$
